study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining yohimbine (an alpha2-antagonist) with fluoxetine (an SSRI) accelerates the onset of antidepressant effects compared to fluoxetine alone.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of yohimbine and fluoxetine led to a significantly faster antidepressant response compared to fluoxetine alone, with higher response rates (69% vs. 42% on CGI, 65% vs. 42% on HDRS) after 6 weeks.
population_specificity: 50 subjects with DSM-IV major depressive disorder confirmed by SCID interview.
effective_dosage: Yohimbine dose was titrated based on blood pressure changes (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin supplementation from Lycium barbarum could prevent macular pigment loss in high myopia patients.
results_summary: High-dose zeaxanthin significantly increased macular pigment optical density (MPOD) compared to high-dose lutein, while low-dose zeaxanthin showed no significant difference. MPOD was negatively correlated with high myopia severity.
population_specificity: Fifty-four subjects with high myopia, categorized by severity.
effective_dosage: Low-dose (10 mg zeaxanthin + 1 mg lutein daily), high-dose (20 mg zeaxanthin + 2 mg lutein daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms by which Zeaxanthin (ZEA) modulates lipid droplet (LD) dynamics and mitochondrial interactions in adipocytes to combat obesity.
results_summary: ZEA inhibited LD accumulation, attenuated adipocyte proliferation, and reprogrammed lipid oxidative metabolism by upregulating lipases and PLIN5 while downregulating FSP27. It also activated β3-AR signaling to enhance LD-mitochondrion interactions and improve mitochondrial function.
population_specificity: Mature 3T3-L1 adipocytes (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Zeaxanthin (Zea) could protect against endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS)-induced cell injury and tau phosphorylation, potentially reducing Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk.
results_summary: Zea showed protective effects against TM-induced cell injury, reduced GRP78 expression, and modulated GSK-3β activity and tau phosphorylation, suggesting potential benefits in AD. The effects were observed when combined with ERS and GSK-3β inhibitors.
population_specificity: Non-RA and RA groups (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Dunaliella salina, including its isolated zeaxanthin, could counteract D-galactose-induced brain aging and dementia by modulating amyloid β protein and neurotransmitters.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin, along with other D. salina fractions, improved motor coordination, memory, and learning in rats, reduced inflammatory markers and amyloid β protein, and increased brain neurotransmitters. Histopathological findings supported these results.
population_specificity: Rats with D-galactose-induced dementia.
effective_dosage: 250 μg/kg of isolated zeaxanthin, administered orally.
study_duration: 2 weeks (administered simultaneously with D-galactose for the final 2 weeks of an 8-week D-galactose regimen).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Zeaxanthin (ZEA) improves obesity by activating β3-adrenergic receptor (β3-AR) to stimulate white adipose tissue thermogenesis and modulating the gut microbiota.
results_summary: ZEA treatment reduced body weight, fat weight, and improved metabolic markers in high-fat diet-fed mice. It activated thermogenic pathways in adipose tissue and reversed gut microbiota dysbiosis, enhancing lipid metabolism pathways.
population_specificity: C57BL6/N mice fed a high-fat diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the effect of increasing lutein and zeaxanthin (L/Z) intake through dietary intervention on macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in adults.
results_summary: MPOD increased significantly in 2 of the 8 controlled studies, but no clear relationship between types of dietary L/Z interventions and MPOD response was found. Limited monitoring of habitual dietary L/Z intake was identified as a major limitation across all studies.
population_specificity: Adults with and without age-related macular degeneration.
effective_dosage: Not specified (studies varied in prescribed dietary L/Z dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Zeaxanthin dipalmitate (ZD) could delay retinal degeneration in rd10 mice, a model of retinitis pigmentosa, and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: ZD treatment improved visual behavior, delayed photoreceptor degeneration, enhanced light responses in retinal cells, and reduced expression of genes related to inflammation, apoptosis, and oxidative stress. It also modulated key inflammatory pathways, including STAT3, CCL2, and MAPK.
population_specificity: rd10 mice (a model of retinitis pigmentosa)
effective_dosage: One intravitreal injection of ZD on postnatal day 16 (P16)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of 1,25(OH)2D3 (vitamin D3) and meso-zeaxanthin could counteract cell damage induced by Aβ (1-42) oligomers, H2O2, LPS, and TNF-α in retinal pigmented epithelial cells (ARPE-19), modeling AMD pathology.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of 1,25(OH)2D3 and meso-zeaxanthin significantly reduced cell damage caused by the tested insults, suggesting potential benefits for addressing oxidative stress and inflammation in AMD.
population_specificity: Immortalized human retinal pigmented epithelial cells (ARPE-19) in vitro.

study_goal: To evaluate whether supplementation with zeaxanthin, along with lutein and meso-zeaxanthin, increases macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and improves visual function in glaucomatous eyes.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant increase in MPOD volume in the treatment group, with the greatest benefit in participants with the lowest baseline levels. A significant improvement in mesopic contrast sensitivity under glare conditions was also observed at 18 months, but no other structural or functional changes were noted.
population_specificity: 62 participants (38 men, 24 women) with open-angle glaucoma.
effective_dosage: 2 mg zeaxanthin (combined with 10 mg lutein and 10 mg meso-zeaxanthin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous Zeaxanthin could mitigate low temperature and low light-induced inhibition of photosynthesis and oxidative stress in pepper seedlings.
results_summary: Exogenous Zeaxanthin significantly improved plant growth, photosynthesis, and antioxidant enzyme activity, reducing reactive oxygen species accumulation and oxidative damage in pepper seedlings under low temperature and low light stress.
population_specificity: Pepper seedlings (Capsicum annuum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential mechanism of lutein/zeaxanthin isomers (L/Zi) in reducing oxidative stress and inflammation in a traumatic brain injury (TBI) mouse model.
results_summary: L/Zi treatment reduced infarct volume, blood-brain barrier permeability, proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, NF-κB), and increased markers of neural repair (GAP-43, NCAM, BDNF, Nrf2), suggesting improved mitochondrial function and reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6j mice with induced brain injury using a cold trauma model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regulatory mechanisms of zeaxanthin-induced chilling tolerance in peppers and its role in improving stress responses.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin pretreatment alleviated chilling damage in pepper leaves, enhanced photosynthetic efficiency, increased antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced oxidative stress markers, and upregulated genes involved in zeaxanthin metabolism.
population_specificity: Pepper plants (Capsicum annuum) under chilling stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism by which Zeaxanthin (ZEA) promotes adipocyte browning and mitochondrial biogenesis, and its potential therapeutic effects on obesity.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin stimulated 3T3-L1 adipocyte browning by increasing specific markers (Cd137, Tbx1, Sirt1, etc.), reduced lipid accumulation, and enhanced mitochondrial biogenesis via the PKA pathway, improving mitochondrial respiration and energy metabolism.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the selective effects of zeaxanthin from Lycium barbarum on skin cells, focusing on its impact on stemness markers (CD44 and CD105) and MAPK pathways in normal fibroblasts versus malignant melanoma cells.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin-rich extracts downregulated CD44 and CD105 in A375 melanoma cells while upregulating them in BJ fibroblasts, and selectively influenced MAPK pathways (ERK, JNK, p38) in these cell types, suggesting cytoprotective potential in normal skin and possible antitumor effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study using BJ human fibroblast cell line and A375 malignant melanoma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Zeaxanthin (ZE) could protect against stress-induced gastritis in rats by examining its antioxidative and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (TOS, MPO, MDA), upregulated antioxidant enzymes and PGE2, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6), and suppressed NF-κB expression. It also improved gastric mucosal damage and ulcer scores by modulating MMP-9 and HIF-1α signaling pathways.
population_specificity: 24 male Sprague-Dawley rats divided into control, ZE, WAS, and WAS+ZE groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a gene-edited Chlamydomonas strain to enhance zeaxanthin production for industrial applications.
results_summary: The double knockout mutant (dzl) showed a 60% higher zeaxanthin yield (5.24 mg L-1) and content (7.28 mg g-1) compared to the parental line. Medium optimization further improved the yield to 6.84 mg L-1 after 3 days of cultivation.
population_specificity: Chlamydomonas (microalgae) strain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential mechanisms of zeaxanthin in human gastric cancer cells, focusing on its cytotoxic effects, apoptosis induction, and cell cycle regulation.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin demonstrated cytotoxic effects on 12 types of human gastric cancer cells without harming normal cells, induced apoptosis via mitochondrial pathways, and caused G2/M cell cycle arrest by modulating key proteins and signaling pathways (ROS-mediated MAPK, AKT, NF-κB, and STAT3).
population_specificity: Human gastric cancer cells (AGS) and normal cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin (Z) and lutein (L) could reduce VEGF-induced neovascularisation and oxidative stress in retinal microvascular endothelium, potentially offering a therapeutic approach for AMD and diabetic retinopathy.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin, both individually and in combination with lutein (5:1 ratio), significantly reduced VEGF-induced tube formation and oxidative stress, with effects mediated via a Nox4-dependent pathway. The Nox4 inhibitor GLX7013114 attenuated these protective effects.
population_specificity: In vitro cell model of retinal microvascular endothelium.
effective_dosage: Combination ratio of 5:1 (L:Z), exact concentrations not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a bacterial strain (GF1) producing zeaxanthin could mitigate thermal and light stress in cultured Symbiodiniaceae algae isolated from reef-building corals.
results_summary: The study found that GF1-produced zeaxanthin restored photosynthetic efficiency (Fv/Fm) and reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in stressed Symbiodiniaceae cultures, suggesting zeaxanthin's role in stress mitigation.
population_specificity: Cultured Symbiodiniaceae algae isolated from the reef-building coral *Galaxea fascicularis*.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic effects of zeaxanthin dipalmitate (ZD) in treating liver diseases, focusing on its hepatoprotective and other beneficial properties.
results_summary: The study found that ZD exhibits hepatoprotective, antifibrotic, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antiapoptotic, antitumor, and chemopreventive properties, suggesting potential benefits for various liver disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of zeaxanthin, alone and in combination with lutein and DHA, on oxidative stress and inflammatory lipid mediators in retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin, particularly when combined with lutein, reduced pro-inflammatory omega-6 PUFA oxidation products (e.g., HETEs and isoprostanes) but did not influence omega-3 PUFA enzymatic oxidation or anti-inflammatory mediators. The carotenoids also regulated transcriptional pathways related to oxidative stress.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 cells (a human retinal pigment epithelial cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Zeaxanthin's effect on brown-like adipocyte formation, mitochondrial biogenesis, and its anti-obesity mechanisms in 3T3-L1 adipocytes.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin promoted brown-like adipocyte formation, upregulated mitochondrial biogenesis markers, reduced oxidative stress, and improved mitochondrial function, mediated by AMPKα1 activation. These effects suggest potential anti-obesity benefits.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocytes (in vitro cell line study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether genetic variants (CFH and ARMS2) influence the response to Zeaxanthin and other AREDS2 supplements in slowing AMD progression.
results_summary: The study found that Zeaxanthin (combined with lutein) did not show a significant interaction with CFH or ARMS2 genotypes in affecting AMD progression. The ARMS2 risk allele was associated with AMD progression, but genotype did not modify supplement response.
population_specificity: White AREDS2 participants with bilateral large drusen or late AMD in one eye (n=4203, mean age 72.1±7.7 years, 58.5% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lutein and Zeaxanthin isomers (L/Zi) could protect photoreceptor cells from degeneration caused by intense light exposure and improve retinal biomarkers.
results_summary: L/Zi administration significantly improved antioxidant capacity and retinal biomarkers (Rho, Sag, Gnat1, NCAM, GAP43, BDNF, NGF, IGF1, Nrf2, HO-1) while reducing NF-κB and GFAP levels, suggesting protective effects against light-induced retinal damage.
population_specificity: Male rats (8 weeks old) exposed to varying intense light conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of wolfberry-derived zeaxanthin dipalmitate (ZD) on alcoholic fatty liver disease (AFLD) models.
results_summary: ZD attenuated hepatocyte and whole-liver injury in ethanol-treated cells and a chronic binge AFLD rat model by targeting receptors P2X7 and adipoR1, restoring mitophagy, and reducing hepatic inflammation. The study demonstrated ZD's potential as an effective treatment for AFLD.
population_specificity: Ethanol-treated cells and chronic binge AFLD rat models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation on brain function, specifically focusing on intra-network integrity of the default mode network (DMN) and inter-network connectivity in older adults.
results_summary: Contrary to expectations, zeaxanthin and lutein significantly increased inter-network connectivity (Cohen's d = 0.89) rather than decreasing it, but no significant effect on DMN integrity was observed. The findings suggest these carotenoids may enhance compensatory integration between brain networks in aging rather than restoring a "youth-like" pattern.
population_specificity: 48 community-dwelling older adults (mean age = 72 years).
effective_dosage: 2 mg zeaxanthin and 10 mg lutein daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of zeaxanthin on acetic acid-induced ulcerative colitis in rats, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and antioxidative properties.
results_summary: Pretreatment with zeaxanthin significantly reduced colitis symptoms, oxidative stress markers, and pro-inflammatory cytokines while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity. The results suggest zeaxanthin may be an effective therapeutic candidate for ulcerative colitis.
population_specificity: Rats with acetic acid-induced ulcerative colitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the treatment effect of lutein, RR-zeaxanthin, and RS-zeaxanthin (L-Z) in rd10 mice with retinitis pigmentosa (RP) and investigate the underlying molecular mechanisms related to endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS).
results_summary: L-Z treatment improved retinal function (higher ERG amplitudes) and modulated ERS markers (downregulated GRP78 and upregulated ERp29) in rd10 mice, suggesting photoreceptor protection.
population_specificity: Pde6b rd10 (rd10) mouse model of retinitis pigmentosa (RP).
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg Lutemax 2020 (diluted in sunflower oil at 1 mg/ml), administered daily.
study_duration: From postnatal day 6 (P6) to P20 (14 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin (OmniXan®) could protect the rat retina from oxidative damage caused by intense light exposure.
results_summary: OMX treatment significantly increased serum zeaxanthin levels, reduced oxidative damage, upregulated protective genes (e.g., Rho, Nrf2, HO-1), and downregulated harmful genes (e.g., NF-κB, GFAP), with histological findings supporting these effects.
population_specificity: Male 8-week-old Wistar rats exposed to varying light conditions (12L/12D, 16L/8D, 24L/0D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing zeaxanthin biosynthesis in tobacco plants enhances protection against UV light and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that transgenic tobacco plants with increased zeaxanthin showed higher photosynthesis, reduced lipid peroxidation, and greater resistance to oxidative damage compared to controls. Zeaxanthin also improved SOD activity and chlorophyll retention under stress conditions.
population_specificity: Tobacco plants (Nicotiana tabacum cv. SR-1)
study_duration: Immediate effects after UV treatment (duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Goji berry supplementation (rich in zeaxanthin) improves macular pigment, serum zeaxanthin levels, and visual acuity in early AMD patients.
results_summary: Goji berry supplementation significantly increased serum zeaxanthin levels and macular pigment optical density (MPOD) but did not improve visual acuity (BCVA worsened slightly). No significant change in serum lutein levels was observed.
population_specificity: 114 patients aged 51-92 with early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
effective_dosage: 25 g of Goji berries per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bioavailability of zeaxanthin from β-cryptoxanthin-biofortified maize and compare its effects between whole-grain and refined forms.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin bioavailability was significantly higher from both whole-grain and refined orange maize compared to white maize, with no adverse effects reported. The study also found no impact on serum retinol 13C-abundance, indicating stable vitamin A status.
population_specificity: 9 adults (mean age 23.4 ± 2.3 years; 5 men)
effective_dosage: Not specified (muffins made from biofortified maize provided for 12 days)
study_duration: 12-day intervention with 7-day washout before and after

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lutein and Zeaxanthin (L/Zi) supplementation could protect photoreceptors from light-induced damage by mitigating oxidative stress (OS) and endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS).
results_summary: L/Zi treatment significantly improved ERG amplitudes, reduced TUNEL-positive cells, and downregulated OS and ERS markers (p-JNK, GRP78, p-PERK, ATF4, ATF6) while upregulating Nrf2, indicating functional and morphological preservation of photoreceptors.
population_specificity: BALB/cJ mice exposed to light damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the modulatory effect of an oil-soluble dietary carotenoid supplement (lutein and zeaxanthin in a 10:1 ratio) on antioxidant enzymes and macular pigments in Swiss albino rats.
results_summary: The supplement significantly elevated antioxidant enzyme levels and total antioxidant capacity in a dose-dependent manner, with notable increases in lutein and zeaxanthin levels in serum and macula.
population_specificity: Male Swiss albino rats
effective_dosage: Two different doses (specific amounts not provided), administered daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the metabolism and health effects of lutein and zeaxanthin during pre- and early post-natal development, focusing on their role in visual and cognitive development and prevention of morbidity in premature births.
results_summary: The study highlights the beneficial health effects of lutein and zeaxanthin, including antioxidant properties, vitamin A precursor functions, and signaling roles, particularly in infant and child visual and cognitive development and premature birth-related morbidity. It identifies gaps in knowledge regarding their metabolism and health effects during early development.
population_specificity: Infants and children, particularly those born prematurely.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NWT-02, a combination of lutein, zeaxanthin, and DHA, reduces vision loss in healthy adults over 50.
results_summary: The study did not demonstrate an effect of NWT-02 on vision, and no cause-and-effect relationship was established between its consumption and reduced vision loss.
population_specificity: Healthy adults over 50 years of age.
effective_dosage: Lutein (≥ 1.10 mg), zeaxanthin (≥ 0.20 mg), and DHA (≥ 170 mg) in egg yolk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of zeaxanthin in alleviating anxiety, depression, and neuroinflammation caused by hyperglycemia in diabetic rats and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Long-term zeaxanthin treatment improved diabetic symptoms, reduced anxiety and depression in diabetic rats, and decreased excessive production of inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α) in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats induced by high glucose and fat diet followed by streptozocin injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with lutein (L) and zeaxanthin (Z) could improve cognitive function in young, healthy adults (age 18-30).
results_summary: Supplementation significantly increased macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and improved spatial memory, reasoning ability, and complex attention compared to placebo, beyond practice effects.
population_specificity: Young, healthy adults aged 18-30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with lutein and zeaxanthin could increase macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in first-generation offspring of parents with neovascular AMD.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant increase in plasma lutein and zeaxanthin levels after supplementation, but no significant change in MPOD was observed. The results suggest that while absorption occurred, it did not translate to measurable macular pigment density improvements.
population_specificity: First-generation offspring of parents with neovascular AMD, free of retinal ocular disease (mean age 56.7 years, 71.7% female).
effective_dosage: 2 daily dietary supplementation capsules (exact zeaxanthin dosage not specified).
study_duration: 6 months of supplementation, followed by a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clone and analyze the zeaxanthin epoxidase gene (PhZEP) from Pseudostellaria heterophylla to understand its role in abscisic acid (ABA) biosynthesis and expression patterns under different treatments.
results_summary: The study successfully isolated the PhZEP gene, characterized its structure, and observed higher expression in leaves and specific tuberous root growth stages. PhZEP expression varied significantly under ABA and fluridone treatments, suggesting regulatory roles in ABA-related pathways.
population_specificity: Pseudostellaria heterophylla (a plant species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of zeaxanthin's anti-lipogenesis effect and its potential anti-obesity roles in adipocytes and high-fat-diet-induced obese mice.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin significantly reduced intracellular lipid content in adipocytes and attenuated obesity progression in mice by down-regulating adipogenic transcriptional factors and genes, while also activating AMPK to modulate energy metabolism.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocytes and high-fat-diet-fed C57BL/6J mice.
effective_dosage: 5-15 μM in adipocytes; 20 mg kg-1 orally in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of zeaxanthin supplementation on in vitro maturation of porcine oocytes and subsequent embryonic development.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin supplementation (0.5 mmol/L) significantly improved nuclear maturation and intracellular glutathione levels while slightly reducing reactive oxygen species, but did not significantly affect subsequent embryonic development rates.
population_specificity: Porcine oocytes in an in vitro setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of one egg (containing lutein and zeaxanthin) affects serum lipid profiles and LDL oxidation in moderately hypercholesterolemic males.
results_summary: Daily egg consumption for 4 weeks increased serum lutein+zeaxanthin levels, reduced LDL oxidation susceptibility, and did not raise serum TC or LDL-C despite higher dietary cholesterol intake.
population_specificity: 19 moderately hypercholesterolemic Japanese males (TC >5.2mmol/L).
effective_dosage: One soft-boiled egg per day (exact zeaxanthin content not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and safety of zeaxanthin dipalmitate (ZD) in alleviating hepatic injury induced by HBV and NASH in non-obese mice.
results_summary: ZD coadministration showed evident therapeutic effects by alleviating pathological events in HBV transgenic mice with NASH. Long-term ZD treatment was found to be safe.
population_specificity: HBV transgenic mice with non-obese non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation in older adults enhances neural efficiency and cognitive performance on a verbal learning task.
results_summary: Lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation appeared to buffer cognitive decline on a verbal learning task (Cohen's d=.84) and increased BOLD signal in key brain regions during learning, suggesting enhanced cerebral perfusion. The effects were observed despite the unexpected direction of increased rather than decreased neural activation.
population_specificity: 44 community-dwelling older adults (mean age=72 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether zeaxanthin could inhibit Pseudomonas aeruginosa virulence factors by disrupting quorum sensing.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin demonstrated superior quorum sensing inhibition compared to evernic acid, a previously identified inhibitor, and reduced the expression of P. aeruginosa virulence factors.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacterial cultures (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize culture conditions for zeaxanthin production in a mutant strain of Dunaliella tertiolecta and assess its potential for enhanced zeaxanthin yield.
results_summary: The mutant strain mp3 showed 10-15% higher cellular zeaxanthin content than the parent strain, with optimal production observed at specific salinity and light intensity conditions, achieving a maximal yield of 8 mg·L-1 in fed-batch culture.
population_specificity: Dunaliella tertiolecta (microalgae strain)
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on culture conditions, not human dosage)
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on culture optimization, not intervention duration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential protective role of Zeaxanthin and Lutein in the pathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy, focusing on their antioxidant, neuroprotective, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The study highlights that Zeaxanthin and Lutein may help neutralize reactive oxygen species and prevent oxidative damage in the retina, with emerging evidence suggesting neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory benefits. However, their role in diabetic retinopathy remains unclear despite established benefits in age-related macular degeneration.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetic retinopathy and potential oxidative damage-related retinal diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin could improve cognitive deficits and hippocampal changes in diabetic rats, potentially via the AKT/NF-κB signaling pathway.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin supplementation reduced blood glucose, improved cognitive deficits, increased neural cell survival, elevated p-AKT levels, and inhibited Cleaved caspase-3 and NF-κB activity in the hippocampus. The study suggests zeaxanthin may protect neural cells from hyperglycemia-related damage.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats induced by high-fat diet and low-dose streptozocin (STZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the association between Zeaxanthin intake and ulcerative colitis symptoms (abdominal pain, faecal blood, mucus, and pus) in individuals with ulcerative colitis in remission.
results_summary: Higher Zeaxanthin intake was associated with lower faecal blood, mucus, and pus in individuals with ulcerative colitis in remission, but not with reduced abdominal pain.
population_specificity: 56 individuals with ulcerative colitis in remission (19 males, 37 females).
study_duration: Dietary records were taken over three typical, random days (2 weekdays and 1 weekend day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of triple combination therapy for neovascular AMD with and without oral zeaxanthin supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that adding zeaxanthin to triple therapy reduced the mean number of treatment cycles and lowered the risk of CNV development in fellow eyes, while also improving cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: 424 patients (543 eyes) with subfoveal choroidal neovascularization secondary to AMD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of zeaxanthin, along with lutein and meso-zeaxanthin, on macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in both AMD patients and healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with zeaxanthin and related carotenoids significantly increased MPOD in both AMD patients and healthy subjects, with a greater effect observed when meso-zeaxanthin was included. Changes in MPOD were correlated with baseline MPOD levels and blood xanthophyll carotenoid concentrations.
population_specificity: 938 AMD patients and 826 healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of lutein, meso-zeaxanthin, and zeaxanthin (LMZ3) supplements on vision and retinal changes in patients with macular telangiectasia type 2 (MacTel 2).
results_summary: Visual acuity improved in 13% of patients, and worsening vision decreased from 25% to 4%. Optical coherence tomography showed reduced cavitations and mild improvement in photoreceptor disruption after LMZ3 supplementation.
population_specificity: Thirteen patients diagnosed with MacTel 2.
effective_dosage: Lutein 10 mg, meso-zeaxanthin 10 mg, and zeaxanthin 2 mg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin inhibits the growth and invasion of human uveal melanoma in nude mice.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin significantly reduced tumor size (56% at low dosage, 92% at high dosage) and prevented extraocular extension compared to controls, with treated tumors showing necrosis and apoptosis.
population_specificity: Nude mice with inoculated uveal melanoma cells.
effective_dosage: Low and high dosages (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of feeding duration of diets containing 20% DDGS on lutein and zeaxanthin concentrations in egg yolks and their impact on egg quality and productive performance in laying hens.
results_summary: Increasing the feeding duration of 20% DDGS diets linearly increased egg yolk color, hunter a* and b* values, and lutein and zeaxanthin concentrations in egg yolks, with no adverse effects on productive performance.
population_specificity: 57-week-old Hy-Line Brown laying hens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review epidemiological studies and clinical trials investigating the effects of xanthophylls, including zeaxanthin, on the incidence and progression of various eye diseases.
results_summary: Increased dietary intake and higher serum levels of zeaxanthin were associated with lower risk of age-related macular degeneration (AMD), particularly late AMD. Supplementation improved macular pigment levels, visual function, and reduced progression to late AMD. Encouraging results were also noted for cataracts, diabetic retinopathy, and retinopathy of prematurity.
population_specificity: General population, with focus on individuals at risk for eye diseases like AMD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of zeaxanthin and lutein on preventing and treating various eye diseases, including age-related macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and others, in experimental animal models.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin and lutein demonstrated protective effects on ocular tissues, particularly retinal neurons, against damage from various etiological factors. Mechanisms included blue light absorption, antioxidant activity, anti-inflammatory properties, and antiangiogenic effects.
population_specificity: Experimental animal models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the zeaxanthin epoxidase gene (MsZEP) in alfalfa and assess its role in conferring drought and salt stress tolerance through heterologous expression in tobacco.
results_summary: The study found that MsZEP expression is tissue-specific, responsive to abiotic stresses, and can enhance drought and salt tolerance in transgenic tobacco by modulating ABA levels and stress-responsive genes. Nodules also up-regulated MsZEP expression under non-stressful conditions and early stress stages.
population_specificity: Alfalfa (Medicago sativa) and transgenic Nicotiana tabacum (tobacco) plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of zeaxanthin on gene expression and biochemical pathways related to skin health using an in vitro keratinocyte culture model.
results_summary: The study found significant down-regulation of 176 genes (including peptidase inhibitors) and up-regulation of 47 genes linked to glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis, with a notable increase in hyaluronic acid production. These molecular changes align with observed clinical benefits of xanthophyll supplementation for skin health.
population_specificity: In vitro keratinocyte culture (EpiDerm tissue model)

study_goal: To compare the 2-year effects of different doses of lutein/zeaxanthin on serum levels, macular pigmentation, and visual performance in early AMD patients.
results_summary: Serum lutein and macular pigment optical density (MPOD) increased significantly in all active treatment groups. Supplementation with 20 mg lutein initially showed the greatest effect on MPOD and contrast sensitivity, but both 10 mg and 20 mg lutein eventually reached similar peak improvements. No significant changes were observed in best-spectacle corrected visual acuity or flash recovery time.
population_specificity: 112 patients with early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
effective_dosage: 10 mg lutein, 20 mg lutein, or a combination of 10 mg lutein + 10 mg zeaxanthin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin could inhibit VEGF and HIF-1α expression in human retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells under hypoxic conditions.
results_summary: Hypoxia significantly increased VEGF and HIF-1α levels in RPE cells, but zeaxanthin (50-150 μM) effectively inhibited this increase without affecting normoxic conditions. The findings suggest zeaxanthin may help prevent or treat retinal diseases linked to vascular leakage and neovascularization.
population_specificity: Primary culture of human retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of lutein and zeaxanthin on visual function in AMD patients through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin supplementation significantly improved visual acuity and contrast sensitivity in AMD patients, with a dose-response relationship observed. Macular pigment optical density increases were correlated with visual improvements.
population_specificity: 1176 AMD patients
effective_dosage: Each 1-mg/day increase in carotenoids supplementation was related to a 0.003 reduction in logMAR level of VA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of meso-Zeaxanthin (MZ) in mice and macrophages, focusing on its potential role in mitigating oxidative stress-related inflammation.
results_summary: MZ significantly inhibited paw edema induced by carrageenan, dextran, and formalin in mice and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines and gene expression in LPS-stimulated macrophages. The study suggests MZ has potent anti-inflammatory effects, potentially useful in chemo-preventive strategies.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice and cultured macrophages.
effective_dosage: 50 and 250 mg/kg body weight (oral) for mice; 5, 10, and 25 μg/ml for macrophages.
study_duration: 5 days pre-treatment for mice; 24-hour incubation for macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with lutein (L) and zeaxanthin (Z) could improve macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and temporal contrast sensitivity function (tCSF) in young healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with L and Z significantly improved both MPOD and tCSF compared to placebo, indicating enhanced visual processing speed in young healthy individuals. No changes were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 102 young healthy subjects (initial correlation study), followed by 69 randomized subjects (15 placebo, 54 supplemented).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with lutein and zeaxanthin improves visual performance measures such as glare disability, photostress recovery, and chromatic contrast.
results_summary: The study found that daily supplementation with lutein and zeaxanthin significantly increased serum levels and macular pigment optical density, leading to improvements in chromatic contrast and photostress recovery, though glare disability did not show significant improvement.
population_specificity: 115 young, healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate potential adverse effects of OmniXan™, a zeaxanthin-enriched product, in subchronic toxicity and mutagenicity studies.
results_summary: The study found no treatment-related adverse effects, toxicological changes, or genotoxicity, with a NOAEL of 400 mg/kg bw/day, supporting the safety of zeaxanthin concentrate.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (10/sex/group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with lutein and zeaxanthin improves macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and retinal sensitivity in patients with early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: Supplementation with lutein and zeaxanthin significantly increased MPOD and improved retinal sensitivity in early AMD patients, with notable effects on N1P1 response densities and mean retinal sensitivity (MRS). No significant changes were observed in placebo groups.
population_specificity: 112 patients with early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of HDL, apoA1, and ABCA1 in the intestinal uptake of zeaxanthin and lutein, and how pharmacological interventions affecting HDL metabolism influence their absorption.
results_summary: The study found that intestinal ABCA1 transfers zeaxanthin and lutein to apoA1, not mature HDL, and that plasma levels of these xanthophylls were modulated by LXR agonists, statins, and CETP modulators. ABCA1 expression and apoA1 acceptor activity were identified as critical for maintaining zeaxanthin and lutein levels via an HDL-dependent pathway.
population_specificity: Hamster model and human polarized intestinal cell culture
interactions: LXR agonists, statins (simvastatin), CETP modulators (dalcetrapib, anacetrapib)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of zeaxanthin dipalmitate (ZD) on alcoholic fatty liver disease (AFLD) in a rat model.
results_summary: ZD significantly alleviated AFLD symptoms, including reduced hepatic fat accumulation, oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis, partly by modulating CYP2E1, NF-κB, and MAPK pathways. No obvious adverse effects were observed in healthy rats.
population_specificity: Rats with ethanol-induced AFLD.
study_duration: 5 weeks (from week 5 to week 10 of a 10-week ethanol administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary supplementation with macular xanthophylls (including zeaxanthin) could reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease in elderly individuals with age-related macular degeneration.
results_summary: The study found no reduction in the risk of cardiovascular disease or secondary outcomes with lutein + zeaxanthin supplementation. No differences in adverse events were observed between treatment groups.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (ages 50-85) with intermediate or advanced age-related macular degeneration, including those with stable existing cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of lutein and zeaxanthin on hydrogen peroxide-treated human retinal pigment epithelial cells and their role in AMD therapy.
results_summary: Lutein/zeaxanthin stimulated cell proliferation and reduced the expression of MMP-2 and TIMP-1 in H2O2-treated ARPE-19 cells, suggesting protective effects against oxidative stress in AMD.
population_specificity: Mice with AMD and human retinal pigment epithelial ARPE-19 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Zn@BP/Si coating on 3D-printed titanium scaffolds could enhance angiogenesis and osteogenesis in diabetic bone defects.
results_summary: The Zn@BP/Si coating improved mitochondrial dynamics, cell adhesion, and migration, promoting vascular growth and mitigating diabetic-related inhibition of bone and blood vessel formation. It also regulated enzymatic activity to prevent excessive mitochondrial fission.
population_specificity: Rat model of diabetic femoral defect, with additional in vitro testing on BMSCs and HUVECs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether substituting lutein/zeaxanthin for beta carotene in the AREDS formulation could reduce the risk of progression to late age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: The study found that lutein/zeaxanthin supplementation reduced the risk of late AMD progression compared to no supplementation (hazard ratio 0.90) and was more effective than beta carotene (hazard ratio 0.82). The benefits were particularly notable for neovascular AMD (hazard ratio 0.78).
population_specificity: 4,203 participants aged 50-85 years at risk for late AMD, with 66% having bilateral large drusen and 34% having large drusen and late AMD in one eye.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of zinc (Zn2+) on dopamine release and uptake in Parkinson's disease-model zebrafish to understand its role in PD mechanisms.
results_summary: Zn2+ photorelease inhibited peak dopamine overflow by 20% in PD-model fish but not in controls. It also altered dopamine uptake kinetics in control fish, with oxidative stress playing a key role in these effects.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (chronic rotenone-treated PD model and vehicle-treated controls)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Zinc sulfate on Pseudomonas aeruginosa efflux pumps and its potential as an antibiotic adjuvant.
results_summary: Zinc sulfate inhibited efflux pump activity in all tested isolates, decreased expression of the positive regulator gene mexT, and upregulated the negative regulator gene mexR. It also exhibited synergistic effects with antibiotics against multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa isolates.
population_specificity: 104 clinical isolates of Pseudomonas aeruginosa from various specimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of zinc sulfate (ZnSO4) with carvacrol (CV) and antibiotics against Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 biofilm infections.
results_summary: ZnSO4 combined with CV showed strong synergy with antibiotics (ciprofloxacin, tobramycin), reducing MIC values significantly and improving outcomes in a mouse lung infection model. CV + Zn with tobramycin yielded the best histopathological results.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 (in vitro) and a mouse chronic lung infection model (in vivo).
effective_dosage: Not specified (MIC/MBC values determined but exact dosages not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (abstract does not mention intervention duration).
interactions: Synergistic with carvacrol and tobramycin/ciprofloxacin; antagonistic with azithromycin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synthesis, characterization, and biological efficacy (mosquitocidal, antioxidant, and anticancer) of zinc oxide nanoparticles derived from Aegle marmelos leaves.
results_summary: The study found that Am-ZnO-NPs exhibited high larvicidal and pupicidal activity, strong antioxidant effects, and potent anticancer properties, including cytotoxicity and apoptosis induction in lung cancer cell lines. The nanoparticles also showed antibacterial activity against clinical pathogens.
population_specificity: Ae. aegypti larvae and L-132 lung cancer cell lines.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/mL for larvicidal/pupicidal activity; 125 µg/mL for antioxidant activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc selenide nanoparticles coated with green seaweed (ZnSe-Uf) against Leishmania major, comparing it to meglumine antimoniate (MA) for potential use in treating cutaneous leishmaniasis.
results_summary: ZnSe-Uf showed anti-leishmanial activity with an LC50 of 7.61 μg/mL on promastigotes and 24.3 μg/mL on amastigotes, but was less effective than MA (LC50 of 17.37 μg/mL and 12.3 μg/mL, respectively). The nanoparticles were non-toxic to macrophages (SI > 10), suggesting potential for further investigation.
population_specificity: Leishmania major (promastigote and amastigote forms) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Concentrations tested (LC50 values: 7.61 μg/mL for ZnSe-Uf on promastigotes, 24.3 μg/mL on amastigotes).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but measurements were taken over 90 days for stability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary zinc oxide nanoparticle (ZnO NP) supplementation on alleviating intestinal inflammatory damage in a mouse model of IBD.
results_summary: ZnO NP supplementation significantly reduced colonic mucosal damage and inflammation, restored gut barrier function, and preserved gut microbiota diversity, with the most notable protective effect observed at 160 ppm.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice with TNBS-induced IBD.
effective_dosage: 160 ppm, 400 ppm, and 1000 ppm of ZnO NPs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a zinc-enhanced chemo-photodynamic therapy for prostate cancer using a targeted liposomal platform.
results_summary: The study found that the zinc-loaded liposomal platform enhanced chemosensitivity and cytotoxicity in prostate cancer cells, improved tumor targeting, and demonstrated good antitumor effects and biosafety in vivo.
population_specificity: Males with prostate cancer (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the green synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles using 'Fioria vitifolia' leaf extract and assess their antimicrobial and anticancer potential.
results_summary: The study confirmed successful synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles, which demonstrated strong antimicrobial activity against 'Enterobacter' and significant cytotoxic effects on lung cancer cells (A549) with low toxicity to standard cells (L929). The nanoparticles showed dual promise as antimicrobial and anticancer agents.
population_specificity: In vitro study on bacterial pathogens ('Enterobacter') and cell lines (A549 lung cancer cells and L929 standard cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular mechanisms by which nano-zinc oxide (nZnO) promotes osteogenic differentiation and bone regeneration.
results_summary: nZnO induced osteoblastic differentiation and bone regeneration by activating the AMPK-ULK1 signaling pathway, stimulating autophagy. The combined treatment of MSCs and nZnO significantly enhanced bone regeneration in mice.
population_specificity: Mouse calvarial defect model and mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biomimetic material combining zinc oxide microparticles and tetracycline-loaded beads to combat persistent bacterial and biofilm infections.
results_summary: The biomimetic design demonstrated exceptional efficacy in eradicating methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli infections, leveraging hierarchical micro/nanostructures and controlled antibiotic release.
population_specificity: Bacterial infections (specifically methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the magnetic anisotropy energy barrier of zinc ferrite nanoparticles via cobalt ion doping to enhance their efficacy in magnetic hyperthermia and herbicide sensing.
results_summary: Cobalt ion doping improved the magnetic properties and heating efficiency of zinc ferrite nanoparticles, with 50% cobalt-doped nanoparticles showing better performance in metribuzin herbicide sensing (LOD: 1 ppm). The study demonstrated tunable magnetic anisotropy and enhanced dielectric properties.
population_specificity: Nanocrystalline zinc ferrite nanoparticles (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Cobalt ion concentrations [Co x Zn1-x Fe2O4 (x = 0.00, 0.10, 0.30, and 0.50)].

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between high-dose zinc supplementation and refractory hypomagnesemia in a postoperative patient.
results_summary: The study found that excess zinc supplementation in a patient without zinc deficiency led to treatment-resistant hypomagnesemia due to impaired magnesium absorption and increased gastrointestinal and renal losses. It highlights zinc-induced hypomagnesemia as a potential complication in postoperative settings.
population_specificity: A 72-year-old male postoperative patient with a history of small bowel perforation and intra-abdominal infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a zinc-based nanocarrier (Zn/Ga@Gd-LDH) loaded with saponin gallate for anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anticancer effects.
results_summary: The study found that SG-Zn/Ga@Gd-LDH exhibited controlled drug release, anti-inflammatory properties by inhibiting pro-inflammatory proteins, antioxidant activity, and tumor-suppressing effects (79.89% viability reduction in MCF-7 cells). In vivo models confirmed reduced inflammation in acute liver injury.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (in vivo), MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro)
study_duration: 54 hours (drug release study), acute model duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO-NPs) synthesized using pomegranate peel extract in inhibiting bacterial biofilm formation on urinary catheters.
results_summary: The study found that catheters coated with ZnO-NPs exhibited sustained antibiofilm activity against multiple antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains, including Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Proteus mirabilis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The slow release of zinc ions from the coated catheters contributed to this effect.
population_specificity: Biofilm-forming and antibiotic-resistant clinical bacterial isolates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nHAP-modified cyanobacterial biochar (nHAP-CBC) in stabilizing zinc (Zn) contamination in soils at smelting sites.
results_summary: nHAP-CBC effectively converted Zn from an unstable to a stable state, achieving a 65.79% conversion rate and a 64.24% stabilization rate in toxicity characteristic leaching after 45 days. The material also increased organic matter content, which played a key role in Zn fixation.
population_specificity: Soils at smelting sites contaminated with Zn.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of zinc chloride (ZnCl2) on Aspergillus flavus infection and aflatoxin biosynthesis in cereal grains and legume crops.
results_summary: ZnCl2 treatment significantly reduced fungal DNA content and chitin synthesis in A. flavus, and inhibited aflatoxin production by up to 99.7% at higher concentrations. The study also observed downregulation of key genes in the aflatoxin-biosynthesis pathway.
population_specificity: Cereal grains (wheat and maize) and legume crops (groundnut and chickpea) contaminated with A. flavus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a hyaluronic acid-stabilized nano-zinc oxide (HA-ZnO) formulation to enhance the therapeutic efficacy and safety of ZnO for acne treatment.
results_summary: HA-ZnO demonstrated selective antibacterial activity against C. acnes, improved stability in acidic conditions, and promoted cell proliferation and migration, reducing sebum secretion and inflammation. Preclinical and clinical trials confirmed its efficacy in treating acne with high safety.
population_specificity: Individuals with acne vulgaris (preclinical models and clinical trial participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of sodium-doped zinc oxide nanoparticles (Na-doped ZnO NPs) on U87 glioblastoma cells and normal HEK cells, and investigate apoptosis induction and gene expression changes.
results_summary: Na-doped ZnO NPs showed significant cytotoxicity against U87 glioblastoma cells while minimally affecting normal HEK cells. The NPs induced apoptosis and regulated cell cycle pathways via up-regulation of TP53, PTEN, BAX, P21 and down-regulation of Bcl2.
population_specificity: U87 glioblastoma cell line and normal HEK cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnONP) could sequester α-synuclein monomers to impede Parkinson's disease progression by inhibiting fibrillation and reducing cytotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that ZnONP interacts with the NAC region of α-synuclein, forming amorphous aggregates and extending the lag phase of fibrillation. Additionally, α-synuclein complexed with ZnONP showed significantly reduced cytotoxicity in SH-SY5Y cells compared to ZnONP alone or α-synuclein fibrils.
population_specificity: In-vitro study using SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc supplementation could mitigate cadmium-induced testicular toxicity in rats during recovery periods.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation effectively mitigated most cadmium-induced testicular damage, including improvements in sperm parameters and serum testosterone levels, and was more effective than recovery alone.
population_specificity: Pubertal male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of zinc supplements on levodopa-induced dyskinesia (LID) and explore the underlying mechanisms in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Zinc supplements restored tissue zinc levels, alleviated abnormal involuntary movements (AIMs), reduced phosphorylated glutamate receptor 1 (p-GluR1) and extracellular-signal-regulated kinase (p-ERK/ERK) expressions, and decreased glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) positive cells in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice with induced LID via 6-OHDA and levodopa injections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the stability and performance of zinc metal anodes (ZMAs) in aqueous Zn-metal batteries by addressing dendritic Zn growth and parasitic side reactions.
results_summary: The study found that combining surface laser texturing with alloying treatment (LT-Zn@CuZn5 anode) significantly enhanced electrochemical reversibility, achieving over 3000 cycles at 3 mA cm-2/1 mAh cm-2 and improving the cycling behavior of Zn||I2 soft pack batteries. The untreated Zn foil performed poorly, failing after less than 478 cycles.
population_specificity: Zinc metal anodes in aqueous Zn-metal batteries (not human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Not applicable (cycling tests conducted over 3000-4000 cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of different zinc levels and a high-fat diet on hepatic lipotoxicity in yellow catfish.
results_summary: Low concentrations of zinc reduced hepatic lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, and ER stress, while high concentrations exacerbated these effects. The study identified the Zn2+/MTF-1/GPx7 axis as a key modulator of ER stress and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Yellow catfish (Pelteobagrus fulvidraco)
effective_dosage: Low (L-Zn) and high (H-Zn) concentrations (specific amounts not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sustainable method for recovering manganese oxides from spent alkaline batteries and evaluate their performance in Zn2+ storage.
results_summary: The study found that the recovered metastable RM-R phase of MnO2 exhibited superior Zn2+ storage performance, with high capacity (214.9 mA h g-1) and cycling stability (98% retention after 1000 cycles), outperforming most reported MnO2-based cathodes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (materials science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc coadministration could mitigate metabolic disturbances, inflammation, and oxidative stress caused by olanzapine in rats.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation (50 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg) dose-dependently improved oxidative stress markers, inflammation, metabolic perturbations (dyslipidemia and insulin resistance), and liver injury induced by olanzapine. Improvements were also observed in homeostatic markers like taurine, coenzyme Q10, ascorbic acid, and vitamin E.
population_specificity: Albino rats treated with olanzapine
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg of zinc sulphate (daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for producing ZnO-wood hybrids with photoconductive and piezoelectric properties using atomic layer deposition (ALD).
results_summary: The study successfully created homogeneous ZnO-wood hybrids with controlled oxide layer properties, demonstrating anisotropic piezoelectric response and UV-induced photoconductivity. The hybrids were also used to fabricate bulk (photo)conductive wood and detailed inorganic wood replicas.
population_specificity: Wood-based materials (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism of zinc ion-mediated tumor inhibition (Znproptosis) using a nanocatalytic system (ZCE) and its effects on mitochondrial metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that ZCE generated abundant ROS, disrupted mitochondrial metabolism via the FDX2/LIAS pathway, and induced Znproptosis, leading to significant antitumor effects (up to 83.81%). Cell cycle interruption and inhibition of the Akt/mTOR pathway were also observed.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal models, given the methods described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between dietary zinc supplementation, sleep patterns, and their combined effect on chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation reduced CKD risk in individuals with poor and moderate sleep patterns but showed no effect in those with healthy sleep. A significant interaction between zinc supplementation and sleep patterns was observed.
population_specificity: UK Biobank participants (2006-2010)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc-biofortified wheat flour improves growth and reduces zinc-related morbidity in adolescent girls and children in rural Pakistan.
results_summary: Zinc-biofortified wheat flour modestly improved head circumference in children but had no significant effect on adolescent girls' growth. It reduced the incidence of respiratory tract infections (RTIs) in both groups but showed no benefits for diarrhoea or lung function.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls (10-16 years) and children (1-5 years) in rural north-west Pakistan.
effective_dosage: Zinc differential of 3.7 mg/kg in biofortified wheat flour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a wearable fabric incorporating silver-doped zinc sulfide (ZnS(Ag)) for real-time monitoring of proton beams during radiation therapy.
results_summary: The ZnS(Ag)-incorporated wearable fabric successfully imaged scintillating areas during proton beam irradiation and showed higher light output compared to a plastic scintillator, though its detection efficiency was lower for alpha particles.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied use in proton therapy patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synthesis, characterization, and biomedical potential (anticancer, antibacterial, and anti-inflammatory) of clove bud extract-derived zinc oxide nanoparticles (CBE-ZnO-NPs).
results_summary: CBE-ZnO-NPs demonstrated moderate anticancer activity against tongue carcinoma cells, potent antibacterial effects, and anti-inflammatory properties. The nanoparticles exhibited high porosity and moderate colloidal stability.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using tongue carcinoma (HNO-97) cells, bacterial strains (E. coli, S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, B. cereus), and mouse macrophage cell line (RAW 264.7).
effective_dosage: IC50 > 100 µg/mL (anticancer), MIC = 62.5-125 μg/mL (antibacterial), IC50 = 69.3 µg/mL (anti-inflammatory).

study_goal: The researchers investigated how salinity influences the adsorption of heavy metals like Zinc (Zn) onto tire wear particles (TWP) in river systems.
results_summary: The study found that Zn adsorption on TWP is highly salt-dependent, with no significant adsorption observed above 12 mg L-1 Cl-. It suggests that Zn forms [ZnCl4]2- complexes, which are repelled by the negatively charged TWP surface, potentially mobilizing Zn into water systems.
population_specificity: River water samples from the Freiberger Mulde, Elbe, Saale, Bode, and Schlenze in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs) alone and in combination with silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) for treating aquaculture wastewater.
results_summary: ZnO NPs demonstrated high removal efficiencies for NH4-N (over 98%) and moderate to high COD removal efficiencies (up to 68.82%). The study also noted significant log-reductions in microbial loads, indicating effective wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Aquaculture wastewater
effective_dosage: 1 mg ZnO NPs/L (Group 2), 0.5 mg ZnO NPs/L (Group 4), 2 mg ZnO NPs/L (Group 5)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the molecular mechanisms of rice's response to zinc toxicity, particularly comparing a mutant (NG3-6) with wild-type plants.
results_summary: The mutant NG3-6 showed heightened sensitivity to zinc toxicity, with severe symptoms at lower concentrations (40 μM) compared to wild-type plants (400 μM). The mutant exhibited higher zinc uptake, increased oxidative stress, and distinct metabolic alterations under high zinc conditions.
population_specificity: Rice plants (mutant NG3-6 and wild type)
effective_dosage: 40 μM and above for NG3-6; 400 μM and above for wild type

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc chelation and NMDA receptor dysfunction contribute to epilepsy-like phenotypes in slc13a5 mutant zebrafish and if zinc treatment could rescue these effects.
results_summary: The study found that slc13a5 mutants exhibited low zinc levels in the plasma membrane, and ZnCl2 treatment rescued neurometabolic and hyperexcitable calcium events, as well as behavioral defects, suggesting zinc's role in regulating NMDA receptor function and seizure manifestations.
population_specificity: Zebrafish larvae with slc13a5 mutations modeling human SLC13A5-related epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a multifunctional theranostic nanoplatform using zinc porphyrin (Por-TR) for early cancer diagnosis and combined PTT/PDT/NO therapy triggered by an 808 nm laser.
results_summary: The Por-TR NPs demonstrated NIR-II fluorescence/PA dual-modal imaging capabilities and significant antitumor efficacy in combined PTT/PDT/NO therapy in 4T1 tumor-bearing mice. The nanoplatform showed promise for accurate tumor location observation and effective treatment.
population_specificity: 4T1 tumor-bearing mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an eco-friendly superhydrophobic coating using nanozinc oxide and chitosan for applications like oil-water separation and antibacterial properties.
results_summary: The coating demonstrated excellent superhydrophobic properties, durability under mechanical stress, high oil-water separation efficiency (>95%), and reusability. It maintained performance after extensive testing, including tape peeling, sandpaper friction, washing, and heat treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (material composition described, but no dosage for human use).
study_duration: Not applicable (performance testing duration described, but no intervention period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of zinc oxide nanoparticles-luteolin (ZnONPs-Lut) on cell death in the AML cell line (MOLM-13) and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: ZnONPs-Lut significantly inhibited MOLM-13 cell proliferation in a time- and dose-dependent manner, increased Fe2+ and MDA levels, reduced GSH and MMP, induced ROS generation, and altered ferroptosis-related protein expression. Fer-1 mitigated these effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study using the AML cell line (MOLM-13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the mechanisms by which zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO-NPs) exert anticancer effects in gastrointestinal (GI) cancers, focusing on apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, and metastasis inhibition.
results_summary: ZnO-NPs generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) that cause oxidative stress, DNA damage, and apoptosis in cancer cells. They also inhibit cancer cell proliferation and metastasis by modulating key proteins and signaling pathways, and enhance the efficacy of chemotherapeutic agents by reducing IC50 values.
population_specificity: Gastrointestinal (GI) cancers (gastric, colorectal, hepatocellular carcinoma)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a near-infrared (NIR) photosensitizing dye, Zn6PTPc, for efficient endosomal escape and targeted delivery of antibody drugs into cancer cells.
results_summary: Zn6PTPc demonstrated high singlet oxygen generation efficiency and effectively delivered immunotoxins into cells, significantly inhibiting tumor tissue growth. The system showed high tumor-targeting ability and facilitated NIR-photochemical internalization (PCI).
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or animal model, not specified for human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of zinc sulfate application in rice nurseries and transplanted crops for improving yield, grain Zn content, and reducing GHG emissions in eastern India.
results_summary: Applying 50 kg Zn sulfate ha⁻¹ to rice nurseries significantly increased grain yield, system yield, and gross return above fertilizer cost compared to compost. Higher Zn doses (100 kg ha⁻¹ in nurseries or 12.5-25 kg ha⁻¹ in transplanted crops) did not further improve yields or returns. Rabi season showed higher yields and Zn content but also higher GHG emissions, with the lowest emissions observed at 100 kg Zn sulfate ha⁻¹ in nurseries.
population_specificity: Rice crops in five districts and four agroclimatic zones of Odisha state, eastern India.
effective_dosage: 50 kg Zn sulfate ha⁻¹ (nursery), 100 kg Zn sulfate ha⁻¹ (nursery), 12.5-25 kg Zn sulfate ha⁻¹ (transplanted crop).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a zinc-cobalt bimetallic organic framework (Zn/Co-MOF) could alleviate inflammation and bone resorption in periodontitis by acting as an antioxidant and promoting bone regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that Zn/Co-MOF effectively protected cells from ROS damage, promoted osteogenic differentiation in vitro, and reduced inflammation and bone loss while aiding alveolar bone recovery in rat periodontitis models, primarily through activation of Wnt pathways.
population_specificity: Human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells, osteoblast precursor cells (MC3T3-E1), and rat periodontitis models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of chiral zinc sulfide nanoparticles (ZnS NPs) as a treatment for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) by assessing their ability to scavenge reactive oxygen species (ROS) and modulate gut microbiota.
results_summary: Chiral ZnS NPs effectively reduced ROS, inhibited inflammatory pathways (NF-κB and NLRP3), lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β), and increased anti-inflammatory IL-10. In vivo, l-ZnS NPs outperformed 5-aminosalicylic acid, improved IBD symptoms, and reshaped gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria and reducing harmful ones.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models, given in vivo data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the suitability of a zinc phthalocyanine compound (dt-ZnPc) for photodynamic therapy (PDT) applications by evaluating its photophysical and photochemical properties.
results_summary: The study found that dt-ZnPc exhibited favorable photophysical and photochemical characteristics for PDT, supported by experimental measurements and theoretical calculations. The zinc phthalocyanine complex demonstrated enhanced spin-orbit coupling, which is critical for singlet oxygen generation in PDT.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or theoretical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of different application methods (seed priming, seed coating, soil application, and foliar application) of Zinc (Zn) and Iron (Fe) on grain zinc and iron content and productivity in mungbean.
results_summary: The study found that foliar application of Zn and Fe significantly improved plant growth parameters, yield, and nutrient content in mungbean, with the highest grain yield and Zn/Fe content observed under Zn foliar treatment. Physiological and biochemical parameters, such as chlorophyll content and photosystem II yield, were also enhanced.
population_specificity: Mungbean plants (field experiment)
study_duration: Conducted during the zaid rabi season (February 2023)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high dietary zinc supplementation at different gestational times on piglet tissue mineral concentrations and gene expression.
results_summary: Maternal zinc supplementation had minimal influence on trace mineral concentrations in sows and piglets, but piglet birth weight significantly affected mineral metabolism and protein synthesis. High zinc diets did not alter sow serum, colostrum, or milk mineral levels, though low birth weight piglets showed differences in tail Cu and Fe concentrations.
population_specificity: Sows and their piglets.
effective_dosage: 206 ppm (Control), 353 ppm (Breed-to-Farrow), and 4,285 ppm (Day 110-to-Farrow) supplemental zinc.
study_duration: Varied by treatment: from 5 days post-breeding to farrowing (Breed-to-Farrow) or from day 110 of gestation to farrowing (Day 110-to-Farrow).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral zinc supplementation as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in treating periodontitis by assessing clinical parameters and salivary MMP-8 levels.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation combined with scaling and root planing significantly improved clinical parameters (GI, PPD, CAL, BI) and reduced salivary MMP-8 levels compared to placebo with scaling and root planing alone. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.01 for GI, PPD, CAL; p < 0.05 for BI and MMP-8).
population_specificity: 42 patients with moderate to severe periodontitis from a tertiary care hospital in India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of novel SAHA analogs, including those with an N-trifluoroacetyl zinc-binding group (ZBG), as HDAC inhibitors for breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that compound 6b, containing an N-trifluoroacetyl ZBG, demonstrated cytotoxic activity against breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231) with higher safety margins compared to SAHA, suggesting improved efficacy and reduced toxicity.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7, MDA-MB-231) and a non-tumorigenic cell line (MCF-10A).
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 76.7 µM (MDA-MB-231) and 45.7 µM (MCF-7) for compound 6b.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of probiotics on cognitive impairments induced by zinc chloride exposure in zebrafish.
results_summary: ZnCl2 exposure impaired cognitive functions and sociability in zebrafish, while probiotic treatment showed partial neurobehavioral benefits, particularly in mitigating anxiety-like behaviors rather than cognitive deficits.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (Danio rerio)
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg/L and 1.0 mg/L ZnCl2 for 96 h, followed by 7-day probiotic administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of co-packaged ORS and zinc on dispensing practices for childhood diarrhoea treatment in low-resource settings.
results_summary: The study found that co-packaging significantly increased the odds of dispensing both ORS and zinc together (OR 8.42) and reduced variability in dispensing practices between facilities, with less well-resourced facilities benefiting the most.
population_specificity: Children under 5 years of age in rural health facilities in Mongu District, Zambia.
study_duration: Data collected before (2016) and after (2017) the introduction of the co-pack.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of a zinc-containing hydrogel in alleviating vulvovaginal symptoms and improving vaginal health.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in vulvovaginal symptoms (itching, burning, discharge) and vaginal health, with reduced vaginal pH and fluctuating CVL zinc levels. The gel demonstrated strong efficacy as a nonhormonal, drug-free treatment.
population_specificity: 37 women with various vulvovaginal symptoms (itching, burning, irritation, pain, dryness, discharge, odor).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intravaginal application of zinc-containing hydrogel).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a zinc-loaded nanocarrier (TGel) for nutrient transport in seed priming and its impact on cucumber plant physiology.
results_summary: The study found that zinc-loaded TGel effectively transported zinc to cucumber seeds and shoots without affecting plant physiology, as indicated by photosynthetic efficacy and pigment indices. The nanocarrier showed tunable physicochemical properties and stable zinc-polymer interactions.
population_specificity: Cucumber plants (seed compartments and shoots)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to generate a high-affinity aptamer (HL15a) targeting ZIP10 and ZIP6 zinc transporters to study their roles in zinc homeostasis and disease.
results_summary: The study found that aptamer HL15a binds strongly to ZIP10 and ZIP6, with a dissociation constant of 1.90 ± 0.49 nM, and effectively distinguishes high malignancy cancer tissues from normal and low malignancy tissues in breast and prostate cancers.
population_specificity: Tumor cells from 48 cell lines and pathological sections of breast and prostate cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer, antioxidant, and antibacterial potential of L-Glutaminase-capped zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnONP).
results_summary: L-Glutaminase-capped ZnONP demonstrated significant antibacterial activity against E. coli and B. cereus, strong antioxidant properties, and pronounced cytotoxicity against MCF-7 cancerous cells with an IC50 of 28.31 µg/mL.
population_specificity: In-vitro studies (bacterial strains and MCF-7 cell line).
effective_dosage: Not specified for human consumption; in-vitro concentrations used.
study_duration: Not specified for human intervention; fermentation lasted 4 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term antibiofilm, fluorescence, enamel demineralization prevention, removal efficiency, and biocompatibility of an orthodontic adhesive modified with zinc oxide quantum dots (ZnQDs).
results_summary: ZnQDs demonstrated long-lasting antibiofilm and fluorescent properties, reduced enamel demineralization, and improved adhesive removal efficiency without damaging enamel. The adhesive was also found to be well-biocompatible in rat models.
population_specificity: Rat subcutaneous tissue implant model (preclinical study).
effective_dosage: 20% by weight ZnQDs incorporated into adhesive.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Zinc Oxide nanoparticles (ZnO-NPs), both individually and in combination with microplastics, on crayfish (Astacus leptodactylus).
results_summary: Exposure to ZnO-NPs led to significant biochemical disruptions, including increased oxidative stress markers (e.g., malondialdehyde) and decreased antioxidant levels (e.g., glutathione peroxidase). The study suggested potential synergistic toxicity when ZnO-NPs were combined with microplastics.
population_specificity: Crayfish (Astacus leptodactylus)
