interactions: Synergistic effects with microplastics (polyethylene, polystyrene, polyvinyl chloride)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ZnO NPs combined with compression therapy in treating chronic venous ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that ZnO NPs combined with a three-layer Unna boot and compression therapy significantly reduced a previously unresponsive venous leg ulcer in a 75-year-old patient. The treatment accelerated healing and offered a cost-effective solution.
population_specificity: A 75-year-old woman with a chronic venous ulcer caused by deep venous insufficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to construct a prognostic model using C2H2 zinc finger-associated lncRNAs to predict outcomes and guide therapy selection in clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) patients.
results_summary: The study identified a signature of five lncRNAs strongly correlated with ccRCC prognosis, demonstrating higher diagnostic efficacy than individual clinicopathologic variables (AUC 0.775). The high-risk group showed shorter overall survival and increased sensitivity to certain chemotherapy drugs.
population_specificity: Patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of activity concentrations and absorbed doses calculated from a high-speed whole-body CZT SPECT camera versus conventional SPECT in patients receiving [177Lu]Lu-DOTATATE treatment.
results_summary: The study found that activity concentrations and absorbed doses from the CZT SPECT system were globally comparable to conventional SPECT, with minor differences in the liver. CZT SPECT was deemed more suitable for clinical routine due to shorter recording times and whole-body coverage.
population_specificity: Fifteen patients referred for [177Lu]Lu-DOTATATE treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on imaging techniques, not Zinc dosage).
study_duration: Imaging performed at 24, 96, and 168 hours post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc ferrite-loaded hydroxyethyl cellulose/chitosan film (ZnFe₂O₄@HEC/Cs) in removing methyl orange dye from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The study found that ZnFe₂O₄@HEC/Cs composites exhibited high adsorption efficiency for methyl orange dye, with the 3ZnFe₂O₄@HEC/Cs film showing the highest adsorption capacity (288 mg/g) compared to pure HEC/Cs (199 mg/g). The composite demonstrated rapid adsorption, reusability, and maintained performance in the presence of common contaminants.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions contaminated with methyl orange dye.
effective_dosage: Three concentrations of ZnFe₂O₄ (0.1 g, 0.2 g, and 0.3 g) were tested in the film preparations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of additive elements and control parameters on the corrosion resistance, mechanical properties, and appearance of hot-dip galvanized zinc coatings.
results_summary: The study found that hot-dip galvanizing techniques significantly extend the life of metal parts by protecting them from corrosive elements. The properties of the coatings were influenced by bath formulation and control parameters, with alloyed zinc coatings compared to standard zinc coatings in various tests.
population_specificity: Metal parts subjected to corrosive environments (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether waterborne zinc (Zn) could mitigate high-fat diet (HFD)-induced hepatic lipid accumulation in yellow catfish and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: Zn exposure alleviated HFD-induced liver fat accumulation and damage by increasing SIRT1 and FXR expression, promoting FXR deacetylation, and activating ATGL to enhance lipolysis.
population_specificity: Yellow catfish (Pelteobagrus fulvidraco)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of zinc caproate (ZnCA) on intestinal health, growth performance, inflammatory status, and zinc homeostasis in weaned piglets challenged with ETEC K88.
results_summary: ZnCA at 1,600 mg/kg improved growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and reduced diarrhea and inflammation caused by ETEC K88, with effects comparable to pharmacological ZnO. ZnCA also outperformed ZnO in enhancing intestinal health and zinc homeostasis.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (Duroc × Landrace × Yorkshire, 28 days old, 7.78 ± 0.19 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of zinc finger proteins in colorectal cancer, focusing on their classification, functional characteristics, and potential clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that zinc finger proteins, as transcription factors, play varying roles in colorectal cancer, either promoting or inhibiting tumor development, and may influence gene transcription and signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature on colorectal cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nano-zinc oxide (nZnO) in alleviating cadmium (Cd) toxicity in Hibiscus syriacus L.
results_summary: The study found that nZnO significantly increased plant biomass, improved photosynthetic performance, osmotic regulation, and antioxidant levels, and reduced Cd accumulation in roots. Leaf application of 50 mg/L nZnO showed the best results.
population_specificity: Hibiscus syriacus L. plants grown in Cd-contaminated soil.
effective_dosage: 50 and 100 mg/L nZnO (soil or foliar application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between serum zinc levels and the severity and wound healing outcomes of diabetic foot ulcers (DFU).
results_summary: The study found that lower serum zinc levels were significantly associated with wound healing failure in DFU patients, and zinc deficiency was independently linked to poor healing outcomes.
population_specificity: 319 patients categorized into healthy controls (n=213), diabetes patients without foot ulcers (n=67), and diabetes patients with foot ulcers (n=39).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a zinc-based metal-organic framework (ZIF-8) composite aerogel for removing toxic metal ions (Cu2+) and Congo red from wastewater.
results_summary: The ZIF@BC composite aerogel demonstrated high adsorption capacities (397.55 mg/g for CR and 424.80 mg/g for Cu2+), excellent selectivity, and reusability, with interactions involving electrostatic forces, hydrogen bonding, and pore diffusion.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adsorption capacities reported in mg/g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of the StZIP2 gene in regulating zinc homeostasis in potato plants under zinc deficiency stress.
results_summary: The study found that overexpression of the StZIP2 gene increased chlorophyll content, antioxidant enzyme activity, proline levels, and zinc transport efficiency while reducing malonic dialdehyde content. Interference with StZIP2 expression had the opposite effects.
population_specificity: Potato cultivar 'Atlantic' (plants, not humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential causal relationship between zinc and the risk of osteoarthritis using Mendelian randomization approaches.
results_summary: The study found a positive association between zinc and osteoarthritis risk, which remained significant even after controlling for confounding factors like BMI and strenuous exercise. Other micronutrients did not show significant associations with OA risk.
population_specificity: Large prospective cohort from genome-wide association studies (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regulatory role of ZNF580 on myocardial ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury and confirm its potential as a therapeutic candidate.
results_summary: ZNF580 increased cell viability, restored cell morphology, reduced apoptosis, and promoted autophagic flux in HUVECs exposed to I/R injury, likely via the AMPK signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether potentiated zinc oxide (pZnO), alone or combined with tannin-rich extract, could reduce post-weaning diarrhea severity and antibiotic use in ETEC-challenged piglets.
results_summary: Both pZnO and tannin-rich extract reduced antibiotic treatment needs, while tannin-rich extract alone or combined with pZnO also reduced fecal scores. Traditional high-dose ZnO improved growth rates, but lower-dose alternatives with tannins provided health benefits without high zinc levels.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (26 ± 1.6 days old, average weight 7.8 ± 1.02 kg) infected with enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC).
effective_dosage: 150 mg Zn/kg pZnO, 300 mg Zn/kg pZnO, 3,000 mg Zn/kg ZnO, and 7.5 g/kg tannin-rich extract.
study_duration: Intervention lasted at least 9 days post-infection (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of green-synthesized zinc nanoparticles (ZNP) in controlling Toxoplasma gondii infection in mice by assessing immune stimulation, antioxidant activity, and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: ZNP treatment significantly reduced tissue cyst numbers and size, improved antioxidant enzyme activity, decreased inflammatory cytokine expression, and inhibited pathogenicity-related factors without observable toxicity.
population_specificity: T. gondii-infected mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different zinc sources on the growth, physiological, and metabolic performance of L. rohita (a fish species).
results_summary: Zinc gluconate significantly improved final body weight, feed conversion ratio, body weight gain, and tissue zinc concentration in L. rohita compared to other zinc sources. It also enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity and reduced stress and immune response indicators.
population_specificity: L. rohita (aquatic animal)
effective_dosage: Zinc sulfate (226.25 mg/kg), zinc citrate (150.15 mg/kg), zinc acetate (230.56 mg/kg), zinc monomethionine (244.75 mg/kg), zinc gluconate (395.94 mg/kg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc oxide-derived nanoparticles (PZnONP) could enhance stem cell proliferation and activation to improve liver regeneration in injury models.
results_summary: PZnONP-labeled stem cells (ZnBA) demonstrated anti-inflammatory properties, promoted liver regeneration, and modulated immune responses in murine models of acute and fibrotic liver injury. The nanoparticles facilitated sustained Zn2+ and ROS release, improving stem cell homing and reducing collagen synthesis.
population_specificity: Murine models (mice) with acute and fibrotic liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore zinc's role in immune function, particularly its influence on cellular metabolism and potential to mitigate respiratory disease risk.
results_summary: Zinc deficiency impairs immune cell function and increases susceptibility to respiratory diseases like pneumonia, influenza, and COVID-19. Zinc homeostasis is crucial for immune cell signaling and metabolism, but the mechanisms behind its protective effects remain poorly understood.
population_specificity: Older adults prone to zinc deficiency (general mention, no specific cohort described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticoccidial efficacy of biosynthesized zinc oxide nanoparticles (Bio-ZnNPs) in mice infected with Eimeria papillata.
results_summary: Bio-ZnNPs reduced oocyst excretion, improved jejunal mucosal status, decreased parasitic stages, and modulated apoptotic gene expression, effectively suppressing E. papillata proliferation in infected mice.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Eimeria papillata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral zinc supplementation could reduce hospital length of stay in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that oral zinc supplementation was associated with a slightly reduced duration of hospital stay (mean difference: -0.43 days) compared to the control group, with statistically significant results (P < 0.0001).
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients regardless of age or cause of admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of zinc supplementation in reducing pain severity among women with primary dysmenorrhea and explore the influence of dosage and treatment duration.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly reduced pain severity compared to placebo, with doses as low as 7 mg/day being effective, and longer durations (≥8 weeks) enhancing efficacy. The treatment was well-tolerated with a favorable safety profile.
population_specificity: Women with primary dysmenorrhea (739 participants across six RCTs).
effective_dosage: As low as 7 mg/day of elemental zinc.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enteral zinc supplementation improves neurodevelopmental outcomes, specifically fine motor scores, in preterm or low birth weight infants.
results_summary: The study found that zinc supplementation enhanced fine motor scores (SMD, 1.70; 95% CI, 0.98-2.43), but overall enteral micronutrient supplementation showed little or no benefits in neurodevelopmental outcomes for preterm or LBW infants.
population_specificity: Preterm or low birth weight infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of zinc supplementation compared to no zinc for managing acute and persistent diarrhoea in children under 10 years.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation improved recovery rates and reduced diarrhoea duration in children with acute diarrhoea, though it increased vomiting risk. In persistent diarrhoea, zinc also enhanced recovery, but evidence certainty was lower due to study heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Children under 10 years with acute or persistent diarrhoea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low-dose vs. high-dose mentioned but exact amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of oral zinc supplementation on T-cell recovery in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to assess the impact of zinc gluconate on thymus output and T-cell repertoire production, with outcomes measured via recent thymic emigrants and TREC levels, but final results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Forty eligible candidates for autologous-HSCT.
effective_dosage: 3 tablets (zinc or placebo) daily for the first 30 days post-HSCT, then 1 tablet daily for days 31-90.
study_duration: 90 days (30 days high dose, 60 days maintenance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess epigenetic patterns in sperm related to socioeconomic status, using data from a trial involving folic acid and zinc supplementation.
results_summary: The study found differential sperm DNA methylation associated with income and education levels, with more unstable promoters in the lowest education cohort, suggesting potential epigenetic dysregulation linked to socioeconomic status.
population_specificity: 1,429 semen samples from participants in the Folic Acid and Zinc Supplementation Trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between serum zinc levels and the risk of covert hepatic encephalopathy (CHE) in cirrhotic patients, as well as the potential for zinc supplementation to prevent overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE).
results_summary: Lower serum zinc levels (below 60 µg/dL) were significantly associated with a higher risk of CHE, independent of blood ammonia levels. Zinc supplementation was suggested as a preventive measure against OHE, especially in patients taking high doses of furosemide.
population_specificity: Patients with liver cirrhosis and no history of overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on serum levels, not supplementation dosage).
interactions: Furosemide (≥20 mg) was identified as a risk factor for OHE development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effectiveness of zinc supplementation and determine the appropriate dose in patients with sepsis.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation did not reduce mortality rates or ICU stay length and did not significantly increase serum zinc concentrations. High-dose zinc supplementation showed no effectiveness during acute sepsis.
population_specificity: 247 patients with sepsis receiving ventilatory management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if zinc administration could reduce the rate and risk of clinical events (first decompensation, HCC, death, and liver transplantation) in patients with compensated advanced chronic liver disease.
results_summary: The study protocol describes an ongoing phase III trial to test zinc acexamate's potential to improve liver function, reduce hepatic complications, and lower HCC incidence, but final results are not yet available.
population_specificity: Patients with compensated advanced chronic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between serum zinc levels and body composition in hemodialysis (HD) patients with zinc deficiency and assess the effects of zinc supplementation on body fat.
results_summary: Serum zinc levels were significantly correlated with body fat weight, and zinc supplementation over one year led to a significant increase in body fat weight in HD patients with zinc deficiency.
population_specificity: 48 hemodialysis (HD) patients with zinc deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand zinc's impact on osteoarthritis (OA) pathogenesis, including its effects on the immune system and bones, and to clarify its potential benefits and risks.
results_summary: The study found that zinc plays a significant role in OA pathogenesis through zinc-dependent enzymes, but both excessive and deficient zinc levels can negatively affect bone health and immune function, making supplementation a double-edged sword.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of oxidative stress and zinc in metabolic dysfunction, particularly insulin resistance, in PCOS.
results_summary: The study found that oxidative stress markers are elevated in PCOS and correlate with metabolic dysfunction, and zinc may mitigate some metabolic and endocrine manifestations of PCOS.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers examined the association between zinc supplementation and mortality in COVID-19-associated mucormycosis patients.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation was significantly associated with mortality in multivariate analysis, suggesting a potential negative effect in this context. The study did not demonstrate efficacy in improving outcomes for mucormycosis patients.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with microbiologically proven mucormycosis (69 patients, mean age 52.8 years, 98.6% with diabetes mellitus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in phase angle (PA) and bioelectrical impedance vector analysis (BIVA) results in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients after oral zinc supplementation.
results_summary: The study found an increase in resistance (R) and a decrease in PA and lean mass proportional to age, along with a negative correlation, suggesting zinc supplementation may influence bioelectrical parameters in DMD patients.
population_specificity: 33 boys aged 5.6 to 24.5 years diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role and metabolism of zinc, focusing on its supplementation in pediatric diseases in developed countries.
results_summary: Zinc exhibits anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and immune-enhancing properties, making it a potential adjunctive therapy for respiratory, nephrological, and gastrointestinal diseases in pediatric populations. It modulates NF-κB activity, reduces oxidative damage, and supports immune cell maturation and cytokine production.
population_specificity: Pediatric populations in developed countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc supplementation in regulating oxidative stress and inflammation markers in multiple myeloma patients post-bone marrow transplantation.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly increased the expression of antioxidative genes (SOD1, SOD2, NRF2) and decreased oxidative genes (Keap1, NOX2) and TNF-α levels compared to the control group, with effects more pronounced by day 30.
population_specificity: Multiple myeloma patients post-bone marrow transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dysregulation of zinc transporters in prostate cancer and assess the potential impact of zinc supplementation on cancer progression.
results_summary: The study found that prostate cancer is associated with altered zinc transporter activity (downregulation of certain ZIPs and upregulation of specific ZnTs), which may help cancer cells adapt to toxic zinc levels. Zinc supplementation trials have yielded inconsistent results, with some suggesting increased cancer risk, possibly due to varying dysregulation patterns of zinc transporters.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cell lines, mouse models (Nkx3.1;Pten), and human cancer tumors (via cBioPortal data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral zinc sulfate supplementation on serum bilirubin levels in term infants with hyperbilirubinemia requiring phototherapy.
results_summary: The study found that oral zinc sulfate significantly reduced bilirubin levels, decreased phototherapy duration, and shortened hospital stays compared to placebo. The effects were consistent and statistically significant at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-intervention.
population_specificity: Term infants (37-42 weeks gestation) admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for hyperbilirubinemia requiring phototherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of zinc in glucose metabolism, its effects on diabetes development and complications, and the impact of zinc supplementation in preventing diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Zinc deficiency is associated with insulin resistance and glucose intolerance, while adequate zinc levels support insulin function and may reduce diabetic complications. Zinc supplementation shows potential benefits for managing diabetes, though more large-scale clinical trials are needed.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients and individuals at risk of diabetes (general human population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore zinc's role in testicular tissue, its potential to enhance male fertility, and its possible mitigation of COVID-19-related testicular damage.
results_summary: The study suggests zinc may play a critical role in protecting testicular function and male fertility, with potential benefits against SARS-COV-2-related reproductive harm, but does not provide conclusive clinical results.
population_specificity: Young men and adolescents, particularly regarding male fertility and SARS-COV-2 infection effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential role of Zinc, among other dietary supplements, in mitigating the progression of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA).
results_summary: Zinc, along with other supplements, was found to play a role in reducing AAA progression by mitigating inflammatory responses and oxidative stress pathways. The study noted positive effects, though specific details on Zinc's impact were less detailed compared to other supplements.
population_specificity: Primarily animal models (exact species not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preconception lipid parameters in both female and male partners, including those receiving zinc supplementation, were associated with live birth outcomes in couples seeking fertility treatment.
results_summary: The study found that elevated LDL and TC in both partners planning IVF were associated with lower live birth rates, but lipid parameters were not linked to outcomes in non-IVF treatments. Zinc's specific effects were not highlighted in the abstract.
population_specificity: Couples seeking fertility treatment (females aged 18-45, males ≥18).
study_duration: Couples were followed for 9 months after randomization and until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary zinc supplementation could impede chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression and improve patient survival.
results_summary: The abstract suggests zinc supplementation as a potential intervention to slow CKD development and enhance survival, but specific results or data supporting efficacy are not provided.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly in low- and middle-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review zinc's biological behavior, physiological effects, and the benefits and drawbacks of various zinc supplement forms, with a focus on recent formulations.
results_summary: The study highlighted zinc's essential role in human growth and development, discussed different supplement forms, and summarized applications in food, medicine, and animal husbandry.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human and potential animal applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential therapeutic value of zinc supplementation in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients and animal models.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation was found to relieve IBD severity, particularly in zinc-deficient patients, by improving clinical symptoms and pathological lesions through immunomodulation, intestinal epithelial repair, and gut microbiota balance. The antioxidant activity of zinc was also noted in animal experiments.
population_specificity: IBD patients and animal models with zinc deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of preconception versus prenatal zinc supplementation on maternal serum zinc concentrations and hypozincemia during pregnancy and early lactation, and assess associations with birth anthropometry.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly increased maternal serum zinc concentrations at 34 weeks gestation but not at 12 weeks or postpartum. High rates of hypozincemia persisted despite supplementation, and maternal hypozincemia at 34 weeks was associated with impaired fetal growth.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women in low-resource settings (Guatemala, India, Pakistan).
study_duration: ≥3 months before conception (arm 1), from ~12 weeks gestation through delivery (arm 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether total alkaline phosphatase activity levels in saliva correlate with serum zinc levels and subjective symptoms of zinc deficiency, as an alternative indicator of zinc nutritional status.
results_summary: The study found that total alkaline phosphatase activity levels were associated with serum zinc levels and subjective symptoms, suggesting a potential link. However, further research with more patients is needed to confirm if this measure better reflects zinc levels in the body than serum zinc levels alone.
population_specificity: Two Japanese women (aged 69 and 82) with hypozincemia—one with zinc-deficient taste disorder and the other with glossodynia.
effective_dosage: Zinc acetate hydrate or Polaprezinc (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if zinc, as part of multimicronutrient supplementation, mediated changes in body composition (fat-free mass and fat mass) in school-age children when combined with physical activity.
results_summary: Zinc concentration changes mediated positive effects on fat-free mass trajectories in the multimicronutrient supplementation group at 9 and 21 months and inversely associated with fat mass trajectories in the physical activity group at 9 months.
population_specificity: South African schoolchildren aged 6-12 years from public schools in Gqeberha.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review zinc's roles in health, the impact of deficiency, and solutions for improving zinc intake globally.
results_summary: Zinc deficiency is linked to increased risk of diabetes and cardiometabolic disorders, and it is a common form of malnutrition. Solutions like supplementation, fortification, and biofortification are recommended to combat deficiency.
population_specificity: Global populations, with emphasis on vulnerable individuals and those with inadequate diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of zinc supplementation on lipid profile and body composition in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study focuses on analyzing zinc's impact on BW, BMI, TG, TC, LDL-C, and HDL-C in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine risk factors associated with the prevalence and development of moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) among children aged 6 to 59 months with acute diarrhoea treated with oral rehydration solution and zinc supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that younger children (6-<12 months) and those from households with lower wealth were at greater risk of MAM. Zinc supplementation, combined with oral rehydration, was associated with a reduced risk of developing MAM, particularly in older children (24-<60 months) and those with higher baseline weight-for-length Z scores.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 59 months with acute diarrhoea in India and Tanzania.
study_duration: 60 days of follow-up after outpatient treatment.
